titleStmt.title: Internet of Health Things: Toward intelligent vital signs monitoring in hospital wards

affiliation.orgName: Universidade do Vale do Rio dos Sinos (UNISINOS)

Universidade do Vale do Rio dos Sinos (UNISINOS)

analytic.title: Internet of Health Things: Toward intelligent vital signs monitoring in hospital wards

biblStruct.note: Received 8 March 2017; Received in revised form 13 September 2017; Accepted 22 May 2018 ⁎ Corresponding author.

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Vital signs Early Warning Score Wireless sensor networks

div.p: Background: Large amounts of patient data are routinely manually collected in hospitals by using standalone medical devices, including vital signs. Such data is sometimes stored in spreadsheets, not forming part of patients' electronic health records, and is therefore difficult for caregivers to combine and analyze. One possible solution to overcome these limitations is the interconnection of medical devices via the Internet using a distributed platform, namely the Internet of Things. This approach allows data from different sources to be combined in order to better diagnose patient health status and identify possible anticipatory actions. Methods: This work introduces the concept of the Internet of Health Things (IoHT), focusing on surveying the different approaches that could be applied to gather and combine data on vital signs in hospitals. Common heuristic approaches are considered, such as weighted early warning scoring systems, and the possibility of employing intelligent algorithms is analyzed. Results: As a result, this article proposes possible directions for combining patient data in hospital wards to improve efficiency, allow the optimization of resources, and minimize patient health deterioration. Conclusion: It is concluded that a patient-centered approach is critical, and that the IoHT paradigm will continue to provide more optimal solutions for patient management in hospital wards.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Patients are routinely assessed during hospitalization by measuring their vital signs. These observations are crucial to preventing health deterioration, potentially minimizing morbidity and mortality, abridging hospitalization time, and reducing costs [1,2]. The process of collecting vital signs in hospital wards varies, and different approaches are used worldwide. In some cases, data is only manually collected, and stored in spreadsheets that are discarded after the patient is discharged. Other typical approaches include collecting vital signs using tablets, personal digital assistants (PDA), or other similar equipment, storing the information in an electronic health record (EHR) for the patient [2]. In some cases (e.g., in the United Kingdom), this data could be used to evaluate patient health status using heuristic approaches, such as the early warning or modified early warning scoring (EWS/MEWS) approaches [3].

With the advent of the Internet of Things (IoT), in which objects can communicate and process data [4], the collection of vital signs could be partially or fully automatized, diminishing the burden imposed on nurses for constantly gathering and storing this information. Furthermore, IoT uses a distributed platform to process and store data, typically employing cloud computing [5]. The use of this platform introduces the possibility of developing machine learning algorithms [6,7] to infer the risk of patient health deterioration, and to optimize resources in hospitals by predicting future patient requirements.

This review introduces the concept of the Internet of Health Things (IoHT), in which objects exchange and process data to monitor a patient's health status. On top of this architecture, we argue for the need to employ machine learning techniques to correlate this data, transforming it into useful information and predicting future issues, trends, and requirements. The concept of IoHT is closely related to the idea of utilizing information and communication technology (ICT) in the healthcare area, usually called electronic health (eHealth) [8] or mobile health (mHealth) [9]. It is also related to the notion of using mobile devices in health services, and ubiquitous health (uHealth), allowing the use of ubiquitous and mobile computing [10] to monitor patient health anywhere at any time [11]. The concept of uHealth represents a paradigm shift from a reactive to a predictive and personalized healthcare system [12].

The main scientific contribution of this article is to describe the possibilities of the IoHT within the scope of monitoring vital signs in hospital wards. The current approaches for collecting and analyzing vital signs are surveyed, and then possible automatic and intelligent solutions to anticipate risks of patient health deterioration are discussed.

The article is organized into six sections. Section 2 covers the stateof-the-art in terms of patient care in hospitals. Section 3 details the ideas behind the IoHT concept, and possible approaches to collecting vital signs in hospitals wards. Section 4 focuses on machine learning techniques for transforming the collected data into useful information. Section 5 discusses the main challenges, and presents future directions. Finally, Section 6 presents the conclusions.

div.head: Patient-centered care in hospitals
div.p: Patient-centered care (PCC) is one of the most important indicators of the quality of care provided in hospitals [13,14]. There are many ways in which PCC can be evaluated, including adjustments to special requirements of patients, the sharing of patient health information, and accessibility to care and services. From an ICT point of view, PCC refers to any medical information system centered on patient-related data (i.e., their EHR). This differs from the traditional approach of many enterprise resource planning systems, which are mainly focused on optimizing the general process and workflow [15].

PCC can be described in three aspects: (1) the vital signs monitored in hospital wards, (2) the use of vital signs to evaluate the risks of patient health deterioration, and (3) the vital signs that can be combined with other preexisting data.

div.head: Vital signs monitoring
div.p: Since the beginning of the 20th century, nurses have performed patient surveillance in hospitals by measuring the same vital signs [16]. These typically consist of blood pressure, temperature, heart rate, and respiratory rate, with the recent addition of oxygen saturation [17]. The guidelines from the National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence (NICE) recommend the observation of six vital signs as a minimum, including oxygen saturation in addition to the five others used in the original score. Furthermore, they suggest that in specific circumstances additional parameters should be considered, including urine output, level of pain, or another biochemical analysis [18]. However, the exact types of vital signs collected vary according to different protocols and methods applied in hospitals [19], representing a topic that is subject to continuous debate [17].

Motivated by the complexity resulting from an increasing patient survival rate and longer life expectancy [20], Elliott and Coventry proposed eight vital signs, recommending three additional measures that should be part of the assessment: level of pain, level of consciousness, and urine output [17]. Table 1 presents the definitions, normal ranges, and influencing factors of the eight main vital signs that could potentially be monitored for surveilling patient health in hospitals.

Other open questions concern the optimal frequency for vital signs monitoring, and how it should be measured and registered. In fact, not all the vital signs presented in Table 1 can be collected automatically. For example, evaluating the level of pain is highly subjective and depends on following specific guidelines. In this context, the WILDA approach verifies five key components to pain evaluation, including words to describe pain, intensity (0-10 scale), location, duration, aggravation, and alleviating factors [25]. Although use of the WILDA protocol implies the interaction between caregivers and patients, some form of electronic registration of the data could also be implemented. For instance, data could be entered into a tablet computer or smartphone to be recorded as part of the patient EHR. Another vital sign that depends on the interaction between patient and caregivers is the evaluation of level of consciousness. This is typically performed using the Glasgow Coma Scale (CGS), which includes the assessment of eye opening, and verbal and motor responses [23]. For each of these evaluations, a numerical value is assigned according to the patient's responses to stimuli. These values could also be registered electronically, for further visualization of the patient's neurological status. In the case of monitoring urine output, there are also devices that allow this to be automatically and continuously recorded if the patient is using a catheter. However, in many cases urine output is still measured using a manual urinometer, or estimated [26].

div.head: Risk evaluation of patients
div.p: One of the key priorities for PCC in hospitals is the monitoring of vital signs at regular intervals, with the frequency increasing when abnormalities are detected. This information is used to assess a patient's risk of health deterioration based on graded response strategies [18]. These strategies include tracking and triggering systems, employing many vital signs to define the frequency of observation, the parameters to be measured, and the time point at which a response should be triggered. Table 2 lists the typical risk evaluation strategies currently used in hospitals.

The first group of strategies is based on monitoring single parameters. Among the proposals, the Medical Emergency Team (MET) calling criteria [30] is the most commonly employed, and is representative of this category. MET is based on possible changes in specific vital signs defined as abnormal physiological variables [27], which includes threatened airway, respiratory arrests, cardiac arrests, sudden changes in the level of consciousness, and seizures.

In the second group, the requirement is the presence of one or more abnormal vital signs. One of the most representative strategies in this group is the Patient-at-Risk Team (PART) calling criteria [28]. The PART protocol consists of a combination of predefined thresholds for vital signs, including respiratory rate, systolic pressure, heart hate, level of consciousness, oxygen saturation, and urine output [31].

The third group of risk evaluation strategies consists of attributing scores to vital signs in order to identify early signs of health deterioration. The pioneer metric of aggregate scoring is the Early Warning Score (EWS) [29]. EWS has been widely employed by most hospitals in United Kingdom, and it is recommended by NICE [2,32]. The idea behind EWS is to closely monitor patient health status by evaluating several parameters at different frequencies according to the calculated values. To integrate the EWS into the patient EHR, vital sign data needs to be registered, either manually or automatically, and the score calculated and visualized over time. These latter steps could also be performed either automatically or by using paper-based EWS systems. The original EWS score was based on five vital signs, comprising systolic blood pressure, body temperature, heart rate, respiratory rate, and level of consciousness [33]. Based on comparing these observed vital signs with normal ranges, a single composite score is generated. Deviations from normal ranges produce a score for each vital sign (i.e., 0-6 for systolic blood pressure, 0-3 for the other parameters), and the sum of these scores is used to calculate the overall EWS [29]. Many variations from the original EWS are currently in use. For example, the Modified Early Warning Score (MEWS) includes urine output as a sixth vital sign, and relative deviation from a patient's normal blood pressure [34]. The VitalPac EWS (ViEWS) is a proprietary system based on a PDA that helps to gather the vital signs at the bedside and to calculate the appropriate score [35,2]. Another variation is the Worthing Physiological Scoring System, which considers ventilatory frequency, heart rate, arterial pressure, temperature, oxygen saturation, and consciousness level to evaluate the risk of mortality [36].

The final group of risk evaluation strategies focuses on combining single or multiple parameters with aggregation scoring, combining the simplicity of the first two groups of strategies with the improved sensitivity of the EWS and its variations [18].

All the methods summarized here are based on heuristic approaches. These methods compare physiological observations with predefined thresholds, leading to a large number of false positives [37]. These types of assessment could benefit from the use of artificial intelligence techniques for a more accurate assessment of the patient health status.

div.head: Registering patient health data
div.p: One important aspect of implementing a PCC program is to record physiological observations when admitting patients to hospitals and during their stay. For that purpose, health providers usually employ EHR systems, which are digital repositories of information regarding the health statuses of patients [38]. Typical EHR systems are controlled by healthcare providers and managed by healthcare professionals [39]. These systems generally focus only on the relation between the patient and a specific health provider, and not on historical health information of a particular patient. Consolidating the information from multiple EHR systems to obtain an integrated view of a patient's EHR remains a challenge [40].

One possibility to achieve an integrated and unified view of patient health status is to consider the use of personal health records (PHR) [41]. A PHR is an individual representation of the health of a patient, which can contain standalone information or integrate multiple sources. A PHR is managed and controlled by the patient themselves, including the possibility of delegating a representative or granting access permissions [42]. Engaging patients into the management of their health information allows better cooperation and involvement in the treatment process [43,44]. Furthermore, the role of the patient in interacting with their PHR changes radically with the use of mobile devices and wearables, allowing real-time vital signs monitoring, complementing health information, and allowing more proactive action [45]. The current trend is the combination of information from traditional EHR systems obtained from health providers with data gathered by the patient using wearables and mobile devices [46] (Fig. 1).

div.head: Internet of Health Things
div.p: The concept of the Internet of Things (IoT) has evolved since its original proposition in 1999 into an interconnected global network, involving sensing, wireless communication, and information processing technologies [4]. At the core of the IoT lie the objects, sometimes called smart objects [47], which have communicating and processing capabilities to autonomously interact with each other. During recent years, many different concepts been proposed to characterize what IoT really means, varying from environmental data sensing to providing services for communications, over analytics, applications, and exchanging Allows tracking of progress, allows graded response strategy, sensitivity and specificity depend on the specific combination.

information [48]. The IoT can be given different interpretations depending on the application context, including things-centric (e.g., from the sensors' point of view), internet-centric (e.g., middleware-and architecture-oriented), semantic-centric (e.g., from the knowledge perspective), and user-centric (e.g., enabling innovative applications focused on people) [48,49]. Here, we apply the general concept of the IoT to the healthcare area, specifically to the monitoring of vital signs in hospital wards. The Internet of Health Things (IoHT) consists of interconnected objects with the capacity of exchanging and processing data to improve patient health. This patient-centric view involves four distinct layers (Fig. 2):

• Acquisition: consisting of smart health objects (SHO), such as med- ical devices and wearables. The main purpose of an SHO is to gather data related to vital signs or other patient physiological conditions. They typically have communication capabilities in one of the many possible technologies (e.g., Bluetooth, WiFi) or standard protocols (e.g., from the umbrella of ISO, HL7, DICOM, and others).

• Storage: in charge of representing the collected data in a highly scalable and interoperable format. We advocate the use of cloud computing (as in the work of Gubbi et al. [48]) given its intrinsic characteristics, including on-demand self-service, broad network access, resource pooling to attend scalable demand, rapid elasticity, and metering capability [50]. More recently, on account of the high latency of health monitoring applications, a variation of cloud computing has been advocated for IoHT. This variation is called fog computing, which provides cloud computing services in a distributed fashion, seamlessly integrating local devices (sometimes called edge computing) with remote resources in the cloud [51]. Another important characteristic is the registration of patient information using a PHR with semantic interoperability.

• Processing: dealing with the analysis of patient data. Instead of using traditional heuristic approaches, we argue for the use of intelligent algorithms based on machine learning techniques. We expect advanced data fusion and predictive analytics [52] to facilitate a better inference of patient health deterioration, optimizing resources.

• Presentation: appearance of results as a combination of the previous layers. These can take the form of alerts, suggested actions, graphs, and charts. Epidemiological views can be obtained by combining deidentified data from different PHRs within a particular context (e.g., region, city, or hospital) [53].

The application of the IoT concept to health services is still in its infancy. However, its potential to reduce costs, increase quality of life, and improve user experience has already been demonstrated [54,55]. From the perspective of healthcare providers, IoHT can reduce service downtimes, identify optimum times for refilling supplies, and efficiently allocate limited resources [54].

div.head: Communication technologies for IoHT
div.p: Many wireless protocols have been in use in the interconnection of wearable health monitoring systems (Table 3). Current technologies used for interconnecting IoHT devices by forming a wireless sensor network (WSN) include WiFi for local area networks and WiMax for broadband wireless networks, Global System for Mobile Communications (GSM) and Enhanced Data rates for GSM Evolution (EDGE) for second generation (2G) mobile carriers networks, Universal Mobile Telecommunications System (UMTS) and code division multiple access (CDMA) for third generation (3G) telecommunication, and Long-Term Evolution (LTE) for fourth generation (4G) mobile phone communication [56].

Personal area networks (PAN) are also widely used in the integration of SHO. A wireless personal area network (WPAN) is a low-powered PAN for a short-range wireless network, and includes technologies such as infrared (i.e., wireless optical communication based on the point-and-shoot principle), ZigBee (which provides a low-energy consumption, but also low transmission rates [59]), ultra-wideband (UWB) (with higher transmission rates and reduced receiver complexity [60]), and Bluetooth and Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) [61]. BLE is a subset of the Bluetooth 4.0 specification, achieving a low energy consumption, which is appropriate for healthcare applications [62].

Another option for communication within the IoHT is the use of technologies based on electromagnetic fields communications, including radio-frequency identification (RFID) [63] and near field communication (NFC) [64]. The original concept of IoT was specifically associated to RFID tracking technology, which typically consists of readers and tags, and it has been widely applied in the area of logistics [4]. RFIDs can consist of passive or active tags. A passive RFID tag uses no battery, being powered by the reader's signal for communication purposes, while an active tag can initiate communication using an internal battery and allowing interactions in wider ranges [48]. The use of RFID in healthcare is considered highly promising, especially owing to the emergence of ultra-high frequency (UHF) tags with increased sensing and computing capabilities, the possibility of powerless easy-to- deliver implementations, and low-cost monitoring and transmission of patients' vital signs [65]. NFC is a contactless proximity communication technology, which works over short distance ranges (in theory less than 10 cm, but in practice around 4 cm [58]). Owing to the proximity characteristic of NFC, along with its ease of use, this technology is very appropriate for allowing interactions between patients and their health records [58].

Finally, low power area networks (6LoWPAN) allow Internet Protocol Version 6 (IPv6) packages to be transported on WSNs to the level of a sensor node, extending the IoT paradigm [66]. IPv6 introduces many advantages to the IoHT platform, including higher scalability, better provision for mobility, and management by multiple stakeholders, allowing better control of smart objects. A vast body of research has mentioned the use of 6LoWPAN as the basis for the IoHT [54].

div.head: IoHT and vital signs monitoring
div.p: Inside hospitals, the IoHT can help to achieve PCC and manage patient-related data. In many situations, nursing staff collect vital signs manually. For instance, they use manual sphygmomanometers and stethoscopes, or questionnaires assessing levels of pain or consciousness. In these cases, a device such as a smartphone or tablet could be used to assist the caregiver (i.e., by providing additional information), or at least to serve as an input interface for collecting data. The possibility of electronically registering vital signs reduces errors and elapsed time compared with traditional manual annotation [67].

Another option for collecting vital signs is to employ wearable technology or wireless personal devices forming a WSN [68]. One trend regarding the interconnection of these smart health objects is to shift from the manufacture standards to the use of IP-based protocols, such as the IPv6 over 6LoWPAN [69]. In the case of evaluating the level of pain, Aung and colleagues proposed a solution that combines assorted sensors to assess pain, including accelerator and location sensors for evaluating activity, audio analysis of speech, and image processing for considering facial expressions and self-reported data [70]. The authors highlighted the existence of many commercial pain evaluation applications for mobile devices. For assessing the level of consciousness, a similar approach that proposed by Aung and colleagues could be used by combining image processing for evaluating eye movement with the analysis of speech for assessing verbal responses and the use of an accelerometer or gyroscope to help determine motor responses.

In the literature, some possibilities are discussed for monitoring blood pressure, body temperature, heart rate, respiratory rate, and oxygen saturation from an IoHT perspective [54,71,69,57,72]. Otero and colleagues proposed a device for automatically monitoring the urine output of critical patients [73]. Many of the proposals use sensors or other medical devices that communicate via RFID, NFC, or Bluetooth to a smartphone to transfer the collected data. Then, smartphones transmit this information further to a middleware, typically within a fog or cloud computing infrastructure.

div.head: Intelligent algorithms for processing big patient data
div.p: In the context of health informatics, big data analytics is meant to cope with an enormous variety of structured and unstructured data, generated from IoHT devices, high-throughput sequencing platforms (i.e., genomics, proteomics, and metabolomics), real-time imaging, and point-of-care diagnostic devices [74]. Furthermore, environmental factors and social media play important roles in healthcare, and can be considered important sources of health information [75]. Big data analysis in this review refers to the processing of large amounts of vital sign data through intelligent algorithms, to identify health deterioration risks and to anticipate possible corrective actions. The vast body of research reporting the application of big data analysis to healthcare during recent years demonstrates the importance of this field of study [76], especially for tackling the issue of increasing data complexity and heterogeneity.

Here, the focus is on approaches based on machine learning techniques concerned with the creation of data driven models [77,78]. These approaches generally consist of three phases: data acquisition and preprocessing, feature extraction and selection, and learning [79]. Data acquisition is accomplished through IoHT devices and any other hospital equipment with registration and synchronization capabilities. Data is then preprocessed (e.g., filtered, standardized, and grouped) before extracting and selecting features containing discriminative information regarding the health status of the patient (e.g., signal descriptive statistics, time and frequency domain parameters). Using these features, a classifier or regressor algorithm is trained to map the relationship between the collected data and the risk of health deterioration. More recent approaches often do not use hand-crafted features, implementing algorithms that extract information directly from the raw data, as in the case of deep learning techniques [80]. Once the final model is trained, it can be used as a decision support system, either to help assess patient health status or to suggest corrective actions.

div.head: Intelligent algorithms for vital signs monitoring
div.p: Various approaches reported in the literature using machine learning could be employed to combine vital signs. Support vector machines (SVM) have been used to create risk scores in a multimodal approach, where data is collected at the time of admission (e.g., patient demographics) and throughout the remainder of the admission time (e.g., laboratory results and vital signs) [81]. An SVM has also been applied to predict daily risk scores for each patient, which were concatenated to generate the risk stratification itself.

Decision trees constitute another method that has gained attention in the healthcare domain. In healthcare, they have been largely been employed for disease classification [78]. Recently, some variations of neural networks (NN) and their combination with other approaches have been the subject of research related to the medical field. One of the first studies in this field applied long short-term memory (LTSM) recurrent neural networks (RNN) to perform pattern recognition on EHR data [82]. LTSM is appropriate in this case because the data series stored on medical records have varying length, sampling is irregular, and there is missing data. In addition, a recent study used gated recurrent units (GRU), a new RNN method, by creating a deep model based on representations of missing data [83]. These research works have paved the way to a new field of research, with RNN applied to medical data, and there remains room for further improvement [84].

Another possibility is to employ deep learning methods [81,85]. These methods consist of NN with many hidden layers and neurons [75]. Employing a large quantity of neurons allows the coverage of a large amount of raw data, while the possibility of cascading various layers allows for a higher level of abstraction in an automatic manner, avoiding manual intervention [86]. This feature is particularly useful for processing vital signs, possibly producing more complex and difficult-to-perceive knowledge from the observation of raw data. Among variants of deep learning, Ravi and colleagues highlight convolutional neural networks (CNNs) as the methodology that presently has the most significant impact in the area of health informatics [86]. Although many studies regarding CNN focus on medical images, some recent works have applied it for the analysis of vital signs [87].

div.head: Discussion and future research directions
div.p: The IoHT lies in a field of research that emerges from the use of wearables, bio-sensors, and other medical devices to improve patient data management in hospitals, with the ultimate goal of reducing hospitalization times and improving healthcare delivery to patients. However, employing IoHT in hospitals presents many challenges. Any technology that deals with healthcare must focus on safety, and security, privacy, and trust should be addressed as the foundation for developing IoHT systems [88].

The first step in applying the concept of IoHT to the monitoring of vital signs in hospitals is the integration of the data obtained from the various available medical devices in the wards. The optimal solution for this purpose would be the automatic recording of this data into the PHR in the storage layer. However, current solutions for the interoperability of medical devices are generally the proprietary of single manufacturers or custom solutions developed by specific health providers [89]. These are based mainly on manufacturer protocols, and present basic network connectivity, including serial communication (e.g., RS-232), wired networks, wireless (e.g., WiFi or WiMax), or Bluetooth [69]. One solution to this problem would be the development of gateways that transform data produced from these devices into more standardized formats, such as those compatible with HL7 or the IEEE 11073 family of standards, focusing on interoperability [90].

Once vital signs are collected, they can be sent to the PHR storage layer in the cloud for further processing. Several solutions for implementing healthcare services in the cloud in an efficient and secure fashion have been reported in the literature [91][92][93][94]. In the special case of using fog computing, data can be processed near the acquisition point, with decentralized edge resources seamlessly integrated with the remote cloud resources. In this case, there are additional challenges, including the balance of load and capabilities between edge and remote devices [51].

In order to use PHR inside hospitals, available EHR systems require more than the traditional functional interoperability, which permits some exchange of information among different platforms [95]. There is a need for semantic interoperability, allowing information to be understood at the level of formally defined domain concepts such that it could be processed by computers [38]. In terms of data representation, PHR can potentially employ web semantic approaches, such as those based on ontologies [96,97]. There are many standards that an EHR system could follow to foster semantic interoperability, including ISO 13606-2 [98], the OpenEHR international foundation initiative [99], and Health Level Seven (HL7) standards [100] such as the Clinical Document Architecture (CDA) [101] or the Fast Healthcare Interoperability Resources (FHIR) [102].

Another challenge related to PHR concerns the integration of data from sensors (e.g., vital signs sensing) with clinical information [103]. The substantial increase in the volume and complexity of gathered data may make its interpretation by caregivers difficult, leading to the challenge of dealing with the six V's of big data: value, volume, velocity, variety, veracity, and variability [74]. These challenges advocate for the use of intelligent algorithms for correlating vital signs using machine learning methods.

Churpek and colleagues compared several machine learning techniques, including tree-based models, k-nearest neighbors, SVM, and NN, as well as linear regression methods [104]. In their study, Random forests performed best for the prediction of the deterioration of clinical parameters in wards. Furthermore, machine learning methods (i.e., SVM, NN, and decision trees) were compared by Kim and colleagues for mortality prediction in intensive care units [105]. They used vital signs, such as heart rate, respiratory rate, blood pressure, body temperature, and oxygen saturation, along with results of laboratory tests, with decision trees achieving the best performance.

The current availability of a large volume of data collected from IoHT devices has promoted the application of so-called "data hungry" machine learning techniques [106], including deep learning. A drawback of deep learning techniques is that despite their superior performance, the results are often difficult to interpret [84]. This opens the door for new research providing better forms of visualization and interpretation, to ease and stimulate the use of such systems [107,108].

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: This review has introduced the monitoring and analysis of vital signs to anticipate risks for patient health, as a starting point for the development of the IoHT. The review opened by discussing the main physiological observations that can be monitored, resulting in eight variables: blood pressure, body temperature, heart rate, respiratory rate, oxygen saturation, level of pain, level of consciousness, and urine output. The article also highlighted the first five vital signs as the most important body measures. Then, the current approaches for health risk assessment in hospitals based on tracking and triggering systems were analyzed. The conclusion is that the currently employed approaches (generally based on EWS or its variations) are mainly heuristics based on predefined thresholds, with few approaches using artificial intelligence.

Another contribution constitutes the discussion of the transition of EHRs towards PHRs, highlighting the need for semantic interoperation in order to foster the integration and exchange of information among different health providers. Many possibilities exist today for the collection of vital signs, including wearable devices with different interconnections, such as Bluetooth, NFC, RFID or UWB, and the possibility of employing gateways for connecting already existent medical devices in hospital wards. Next, we discussed the use of machine learning to process vital signs. Many challenges arise in the IoHT concept, presenting various opportunities for future work and research in the field.

A new vision arises from the IoHT, shifting from a reactive approach to symptoms and pathologies to a more proactive and personalized approach. The growth and widespread adoption of this technology for monitoring vital signs can lead to the prediction of future conditions for the patient, making it possible that medical staff can anticipate actions, such as treatments and interventions. In this manner, the IoHT paradigm will provide more optimal solutions for patient management in hospital wards. In working towards this goal, the adoption of a patientcentered approach is critical.

note.p: Source: This table compiles data partially obtained from[4,48,57,58].
